description: Demolition of conservatory and erection of part single, part two storey rear extension, 2no. second floor side extensions, hipped roof forms on the existing single storey side extensions, plus external alterations, including changes to the fenestration, installation of roof lights and conversion of garage to habitable room
decision_conditions: The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of this permission. Reason: As required by Section 91 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990, as amended by Section 51 of the Planning and Compulsory Purchase Act 2004.

The development hereby permitted shall be carried out in accordance with the materials specified on the approved plans and on the application form unless otherwise agreed in writing by the Local Planning Authority. Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Before the beneficial occupation of the development hereby permitted, the referenced windows shall be constructed so that no part of the framework less than 1.7m above finished floor level shall be openable. Any part below that level shall be fitted with, and retained in, obscure glazing to a minimum of level 3 on the standard scale. The referenced windows are as follows: a) The first floor window fitted in the front elevation serving the room labelled as "ensuite" on drawing number 01 Proposed First Floor Plan b) The first floor windows fitted in the rear elevation serving the rooms labelled "bathroom" and "ensuite" on drawing number 01 Proposed First Floor PlanAny film used to achieve the requisite obscurity level shall be non-perishable and tamper-proof, and shall be replaced immediately in the event that it ceases to result in obscurity to level 3. Reason: To safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers, in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The roof of the single storey extensions hereby permitted shall not be converted or used as a balcony or a sitting out area, and no access shall be gained except for maintenance purposes.Reason: To protect the amenities and privacy of the adjoining residential properties in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

IntroductionThis application is of a nature where the Council's Constitution delegates the authority to make thedecision to Officers rather than it being decided by a Committee of Councillors.Before preparing this summary report a Planning Officer has familiarised themselves with theapplication site and its planning history, the relevant legislation and guidance, considered anyrelevant case law, and considered any comments made by those interested in the application suchas consultees with specialist knowledge and nearby residents.

Officer ReportApplication SiteThe site comprises a semi detached dwelling adjacent to Southborough Conservation Area and St. Matthews Avenue Local Area of Special Character. Proposal The applicant seeks planning permission for conversion of the existing garage to a habitable room including alterations to the roof, insertion of 1no rooflight and associated changes to fenestration. Consultations4 properties were notified of the proposal. No representations were received.  Surbiton Conservation Area Advisory Committee - no objections subject to the proposed windows matching the existing ones in terms of style and materials. The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- The impact of the development on highways and transportation; and,- Fire SafetyCharacter and AppearanceWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed new flat roof would feature a roof lantern and would be of the total height of approximately 2.9m. Considering that the proposed materials would match the existing ones in terms of appearance and quality, the proposed conversion of garage, the new roof form and associated changes to fenestration would be acceptable in terms of scale, form and design and they would relate well to the host dwelling. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the existing street scene and the surrounding area as a result of the proposed development.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  It is considered that the proposed development due to its siting and modest scale would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Car ParkingPolicy T6 of the London Plan 2021 states that car parking should be restricted in line with levels of existing and future public transport accessibility and connectivity. The maximum standards as set out in policies T6.1 to T6.5 should be applied to development proposals. Where provided, each motorcycle parking space should count towards the maximum for car parking spaces at all use classes.Policy DM9, Policy DM10 and the Council's Sustainable Transport SPD 2013 together require development proposals to comply with the car parking standards in the London Plan.Policy T5 of the London Plan 2021 states that developments should provide cycle parking at least in accordance with the minimum standards set out in Table 10.2 and Figure 10.3.Officer Comment: Despite the loss of the existing garage, it is considered that the hardstanding to the front of the dwelling remains of an adequate size to accommodate one off street car parking space, which reflects the existing situation. In relation to cycle parking, officers note that access to the garden will remain so it is possible for secure cycle parking to be provided in the garden despite the loss of possible storage within the existing garage. Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.
